content.body: IE blog says support for Access Control is completed for the next public release of IE8: http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2009/01/14/completing-access-control-support-for-xdomainrequest.aspx
https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/ViewFeedback.aspx?FeedbackID=350052 - they closed my bug as wontfix seemingly without looking at the tests
has now reopened and removed tests that pass in ie8
hsivonen: getting "Bad MD5 hash for http://archive.apache.org/dist/ant/binaries/apache-ant-1.7.0-bin.zip."
when I try to build from fresh checkout
I remember this happening before
hmm, but seems to be OK after I re-started the build
http://esw.w3.org/topic/PF/XTech/MarkUp/Hybrid
zcorpan: words of wisdom

though "Validating only fragments of a document, where each fragment is of a different document type than the other fragments in the document, is beyond the scope of this framework - since it would require technology that is not yet defined." is not actually correct
I wonder what the context was for Gregory writing up that page
http://www.w3.org/2009/01/14-pf-minutes.html (search for "hybrid") (W3C Member-only)
hsivonen: fwiw, after doing a fresh checkout, I'm no longer seeing the "Element “html” from namespace “http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml” not allowed in this context." errors
hsivonen: is there any way to do a "distclean" or "clean" with your build setup? (short of checking out fresh sources)
zcorpan: thanks
interesting
i thought cdf were focusing on filling the gaps in specs when they were used in the same document - not particularly addressing validation
zcorpan: yeah, that sounds correct as far as I understand it
but I didn't really follow CDF when it was active
and it hasn't been active for quite a while now
the problem of validation of compound documents seems already solved by NVDL
so I can't see that there's anything the CDF WG would have needed to do to address validation, other than to just reference that
since it's an ISO standard
indeed
I would think Gregory would already know about NVDL
but that "since it would require technology that is not yet defined" comment would seem to suggest that he doesn't
unless I'm misunderstanding what he's describin
wonders if ap is still cranking through work on full appcache implementation, and how close his is to completing it
MikeSmith: yes, I plan to fix some more bugs - I think that feature-wise, we only lack dynamic entries now, and those I don't intend to implement yet
ap: I thought I had seen you posted a code review for dynamic entries recently
MikeSmith: I started the work, and then realized that I didn't like the spec, see https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=23165#c6
looks now
ap: I see
so, seems like the spec needs to be changed
MikeSmith: the best way to change it may be to drop dynamic entries entirely - we have localStorage and SQL database for that
ap: I hadn't thought of it that way
but unless other implementors are specifically asking for dynamic entries, I'd bet that Hixie might be quite glad to drop it
MikeSmith: there's no clean or distclean
hsivonen: OK
but maybe there ought to be
because I'm definitely seeing different behavior (tests failing) in sources built from my existing workspace vs. built from fresh checkout
s/sources built/code built/
MikeSmith: filed http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=436
thanks
hsivonen: ↑
MikeSmith: I have no idea why the test behave differently in the two cases
hsivonen: I did a bit more poking around and couldn't find any clues either
Philip`: Yes. I could well have broken that'
annevk: I literally have no idea what pms.n does. It runs code that you wrote as a frontend to code that gsnedders wrote :)
annevk: gettters-setters - s/t//
Philip`: BTW my non-scientific tests suggested that the changes I have made to html5lib on the mathML+SVG branch introduce about a 5% performance regression
Although that was only based on one run so I guess it isn't too accurate
annevk: AFAICT you can't get the HTML 4 doctype at the moment. Shall I consider that a feature request? How urgent is it?
zcorpan, hmm, too late
jgraham, pretty printing ain't working
jgraham, euhm... it's not that urgent, because of pretty printing
jgraham, I suppose I could write a post-processor, but that defeats the purpose
that's basically the advantages of the W3C private one, a DOCTYPE that works for W3C publications and "pretty" source code
annevk: I can look at both problems. If it is blocking your work I guess I can even do it today
I suppose pretty printing I can fix to some extent by having more closing tags, although the serializer in place omits <head> and <body> which doesn't help
(but don't write a post-processor, that makes no sense)
it's not blocking my work, as I said, I can use the W3C private one
ok
it's just that using anolis seems way cooler and it generates better IDs and all
annevk: OK I will make it a priority to fix over the weekend or something

yo: editorial question r/e the spec for <small>:  " "legal restrictions, such as copyrights or other disadvantages". I suggest that "caveats" be substitued for "copyright" as a  copyright isn't necessarily a "disadvantge" (unless you're Richard Stallman)
brucel, I've just looked at your HTML5 element test page and the layout doesn't work in Firefox 2. Your blog layout is also rather b0rked. Shall I e-mail screenshots to you?
BenMillard, Firefox 2 is known not to work with HTML5 stuff
BenMillard, it has a bug they fixed in 3 :)
annevk, Bruce's tests are interested in browsers as old as IE6.
jgraham, cool
BenMillard, but Firefox 2 does not have 20% market share
BenMillard: Are you aware of http://www.gijsk.com/blog/2009/01/zeven-zonderlinge-zaken/
jgraham, yes I declined it via e-mail.
annevk, wow Firefox 2 is the source of only 3.7% of traffic to my own website.
BenMillard: Ah, boring ;)
at my site it's 5% out of 50%
annevk, all versions of Opera add up to 5.5%, all Firefox add up to 44%, all IE 45%
BenMillard: I am really not sure why you prefer FF2 to 3
IE is 23% on mine
jgraham, I tried it for a week and found it really annoying.
guess that's still too much to remove the IE hacks I have in place
BenMillard: That wasn't really an answer to the question :) What did you find annoying?
is pretty interested in UI but very bad at designing it
jgraham, it made me less efficient than I am in Firefox 2.
jgraham, there was so much hype about it's UI being an amazing leap forwards, yet it hardly seemed different at all when I used it. So I felt slightly let down by it, too.
jgraham, I've also seen many many reports from people for whom it is crashing a lot.
jgraham, Firefox 2 hasn't crashed for me in...erm...actually I can't remember when it last did. (Several months, probably.)
jgraham, oh and I couldn't find a good XP-like theme for Fx3, despite there being a big fanfare about OS Integration for Fx3. Another source of disappointment.
BenMillard: I can't imagine working without the kind of awesomebar thing in FF3, recent Opera, etc. (I can't comment on stability since I have nightly builds of every browser I run)
jgraham, trying to upgrade my parents to Fx3 went badly, too: http://projectcerbera.com/blog/2008/12/fx2
BenMillard: all I can say is, your experiences are not typical
roc, I expect that's true. I still love Firefox 2, though. :)
People should write software that automatically introduces new bugs at an exponential rate after the next version of the software has been released, to encourage people to upgrade
annevk, Safari is 3.2% of my website's traffic; nearly as much as Firefox 2. (These percentages are from the 135,072 hits I've had so far this month, as recorded by AWstats 6.7.)
BenMillard: of course there's a Firefox 2 theme for Firefox 3: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/6898
BenMillard: Firefox 3 on XP looks quite XPish to me
svl, Firefox 2's default theme doesn't quite fit XP. The tabs are wrong, for starters. That's why I use Fx2 with Winestripe.
ah, winestripe, not winstripe. (sorry, not that aware of Firefox themes)
svl, thanks for trying though. :)

BenMillard: the most recent comment on the winestripe addons page points to http://webdesigns.ms11.net/winstripethemes.html as having the same for Firefox 3 (even though on that page it's called winstripe again?)
Ah, which points to https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/9172 which says "this is the Firefox 3 version of Winestripe"
man, what a mess. :)
svl, now that's more like it! "Updated 9 December 2008" explains why I haven't found it before.
roc, a comment on that theme says: "Thank you for this theme, i was using one on Firefox 2.x and wouldn't upgrade to 3.0 until i had this theme." :P
BenMillard: Two people out of a hundred million does not make it a typical case :-p
Philip`, I'm not saying it's commonplace, just pointing out it exists. Also, the description says: "Without this theme, I can’t use Firefox 3. And I’m not alone in this case."
Okay, so it's at least three people (you, the theme author, and the commenter)
Philip`, 1,181 total downloads.
wants to bet there'll be at least 100 Firefox themes that people say similar things about.
BenMillard: The problem is that when you change anything there wll always be some people who prefer the old way. The trick is to make more people prefer the new way
Right back to Orbit 3.1
(for example people spend a lot of time maintaining SeaMonkey even though Firefox is vastly more popular)

jgraham, what I am confused by is why a custom theme does a better job of following the OS look-and-feel on XP than the Fx3 default theme. Especially when "OS Integration" was promoted so heavily as a benefit of Fx3.
svl, the difference here is the theme follows the operating system, which is what should be the case by default (imho). :)
BenMillard: I doin't have access to XP so I couldn't say
The FF3 XP theme doesn't really look non-XPish to me
uses all his OSs with the default theme and desktop picture
uses Linux so he doesn't expect an entirely consistent look-and-feel anyway

hsivonen, jgraham & Philip`: one example is the standard style of the current tab on XP. They have a white background with a yellow bar across the top and black text in the normal weight. Yet Firefox hasn't used that style since Fx1.5 (iirc) and even then it had bold text.
uses Gnome on Linux so he does expect a consistent Look & Feel but is sometimes disappointed
BenMillard: Do any applications actually use the standard tab style on XP?
I assume IE doesn't, and I assume Office doesn't, and I assume Visual Studio doesn't, and I can't think of any other applications I might use that might have tabs
Philip`, everything which uses standard controls and avoids breaking XP theming support does.
BenMillard: That still doesn't answer the question of whether any applications do that :-p
lol :D
Tools > Options in Windows Media Player 10, IE6 and IE7 does.
control Panel stuff and propety sheets throughout the OS generally do, apart from in really old networking dialogs which break XP theming support so they look Windows 95-ish
Opera 9.63 does, although the tabs are taller than default and the difference in height between selected tab and normal tab is less than standard
Outlook Express 6 uses standard tabs throughout
Okay, so maybe there's a few :-)
It's common enough to notice when it's been done wrong, let me put it that way. ;)
doesn't entirely like how you have to mess around with comctl versioning manifest stuff when compiling Windows applications, in order to opt-in to the new XP themed widget stylings
(though it does make sense in terms of not breaking compatibility with old applications that made unreasonable assumptions)

brucel and I have been discussing this on skype. Who here thinks brucel's use of <small> for the list items in this blog post is a valid use of <small>, as defined in the spec? http://www.brucelawson.co.uk/2009/redesigning-with-html-5-wai-aria/
personally, I think it's questionable and isn't what <small> was intended for. But I could be wrong
Lachy: if he says it's small print, clearly he intends it to represent small print
though i probably wouldn't use <small>
Lachy: It looks weird but no one will actually care hich element he uses so it doesn't matter much anyway :)
because it makes the text harder to read
the point is brucel was saying how he wanted to be able to use one <small> around the whole <ul>, instead of one in each <li>
might make sense - small print is sometimes several paragraphs
I'm leaning toward "valid use"

although having <a>, <ins> and <del> as such elements is painful enough as it is
oop. 20.9k
20.9k is still ridiculously high
indeed
the guy has written 727 answers
I have 35k karma on reddit, but that's over several years of using it as my de-facto bookmark manager

"HTML5 is not a coherent HTML specification, it's Hixie's sprawling, unreadable and unfinished recipe for every random thing he thinks a web browser should do. It will fail. And W3's alternative approach, XHTML2, has already failed. There is no coherent future direction for web standards. We have dropped the ball." -- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/432933/will-html-5-validation-be-worth-the-candle#434044
it'd be nice if people who made comments like that were a little more specific about what needs fixing
Lachy: It's hard to be more specific when they are objecting to the concept of something rather than the details. But I would argue that they are quantitatively wrong i.e. HTML5 has already succeeded

rubys: It is easy to just have a flag that means "don't set namespaces on HTML elements"

hsivonen: Maybe. But in the non-namespace case it is by far the nicest python tree-from-angle-bracket-markup API. It sucks that I should be forced to choose beteen using the XHTML namespace everywhere for no reason or using a less nice tree API
jgraham, seems like a limitation of Python though
not really something we should hardwire in HTML5

arrives
(this also affects XPath in web browsers AFAICT)
nobody has ever defined how that should work so it seems like we could define that in any way we'd like :)
i.e. make it work the same
annevk: FWIW I agree that all _browsers_ should be required to do the same thing here. I don't think it should affect other UAs though
annevk: At the moment, in gecko, XPath in XHTML requires that you implement a NSResolver whilst otherwise you should not
I know
fixing it to be the same everywhere is a stronger argument than one that relies on the limitations of a particular Python library (however popular it might be)
jgraham: that can be solved by using Selectors API :-)

rubys: I don't think that it is just one library though. I think there are lots of cases where tree APIs make life hard with namespaces everywhere. I think the result is that many people will be prepared to break the spec in order to make their user's lives easier

needs to number the title page of his LaTeX document

Sadly, I probably ought to follow what the exam board says
notes no marks are actually given for it, but he still probably ought to
just add a note at the end that LaTeX disagreed

has already ignored half of what he's meant to do, though, to be fair
each page should be numbered, including the title page and the bibliography
each page should be single-sided
each page should be typed in single line spacing
the font used should be Times New Roman
the font size should be 12 point
your text should be left-justified
titles of texts - novels, plays, poems, critical or reference works - should be in italics, without quotation marks
quotations, unless only a few words long (when quotation marks should be used), should be preceded and followed by a double line space.
Fun :\
if an exam board and LaTeX disagree, chances are LaTeX is right but complying with the board might still be the smart thing to do
